awd_titl_txt: RUI: Hfq and sRNA Function in Shewanella oneidensis Growth and Adaptation to Stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Changes in environmental conditions control the expression of bacterial small noncoding RNAs (sRNAs) that regulate the expression of other genes. Though sRNAs play important roles in adjusting bacterial gene expression and physiology, there are significant hurdles to understanding their function. This project combines genetic, physiological, and transcriptomic approaches to identify sRNA genes and elucidate how expression of these sRNAs impacts bacterial cell physiology. This work is being performed in Shewanella oneidensis, a bacterium with the intriguing capacity to respire using metals in the place of oxygen. Students participate fully in all aspects of the study, including experimental design, performing experiments, data analyses, and manuscript preparation and revision. Students also regularly present their work at scientific conferences.  The principle investigator and his students participate in community outreach by mentoring local primary and secondary school students performing science projects.

The project will investigate the role of a highly-conserved RNA chaperone molecule, Hfq, in regulation of sRNA signaling in S. oneidensis metabolism and stress responses. The research couples discovery-based systematics (next generation RNA sequencing) with molecular, genetic, and physiological approaches. RNA-Seq is used to identify putative sRNAs expressed under conditions of interest. Manipulating sRNA expression using genetic loss-of-function and gain-of-function approaches will be used to test whether sRNAs regulate predicted mRNA targets and to determine how sRNA expression impacts cell physiology.  Given the large number of sRNA genes in bacteria, this study focuses on sRNA functions likely to be linked to the metal reducing metabolism of S. oneidensis.  Results from the research effort will be disseminated through peer-reviewed journal publications, and through presentations at regional, national, and international meetings.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this work was to understand how bacteria adapt to normal stress during growth. This includes adapting to reactive oxygen species such as hydrogen peroxide which is produced during growth when oxygen is present. In previous work we showed that a strain of the bacterium Shewanella oneidensis lacking the gene hfq is hypersensitive to hydrogen peroxide, has growth defects, survives extended growth poorly, and accumulates less biomass compared to the non-mutant strain.

In our work for this award, we unexpectedly discovered that multiple hfq mutant traits are due to hydrogen peroxide sensitivity. A key insight in this work was that survival in long-term cultures was highly dependent on the initial nutrient concentration in the medium. Higher nutrient density resulted in lower cell survival. This could be quite striking, with some cultures with high nutrient concentrations dying completely. We demonstrated that cultures with more nutrients accumulated higher hydrogen peroxide levels, leading to lower cell viability. This work indicates that multiple hfq mutant traits are the result of its hydrogen peroxide hypersensitivity. For example, increased cell death rates because of hydrogen peroxide hypersensitivity likely explains why fewer hfq mutant cells survive death phase and why hfq mutant cultures produce fewer total viable cells at maximum density. An important outcome of this work is a better understanding of how hydrogen peroxide stress impacts many aspects of bacterial cultures. In future studies, we hope to elucidate the precise mechanisms by which Hfq helps S. oneidensis survive hydrogen peroxide stress.

Because this award funded work at a primarily undergraduate institution, an important outcome of this work was undergraduate and high school student training. During the period of this award, a total of 11 undergraduate students, 2 local high school students, and a postdoctoral fellow worked on and were trained through this project. Importantly, the postdoctoral fellow, who helped train the students, now holds a tenure-track faculty position at Framingham State University. These students were directly involved in performing experiments, collecting data, analyzing data, and presenting the work in poster form at local and regional scientific conferences. Some of these students will be co-authors on our manuscripts detailing this work that we will submit by the end of 2022. The analytical and communication skills these students have developed are portable to a wide variety of career paths. In addition, the research experiences are valuable as students discern their interests and future career paths.
